pages.altText: Magnified immune cells in a cluster formation

pageData.text: Photosynthesis provides the energy for the fixation of carbon dioxide by photosynthetic organisms. CO<sub>2</sub> is combined into sugars, which other organisms can consume. In this lab investigation, photosynthetic pigments will be isolated and separated from leaves of a green plant using paper chromatography. An additional experiment is conducted that looks at the effect that various conditions have on the production of oxygen as an indicator of photosynthesis.

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.desc:
Preparation - 20 minutes 
Activity 1: Plant Pigments Overview - 20 minutes 
Activity 2: Leaf Disk Assay Overview - 120 minutes
pageData.altText:
Preparation - 20 minutes

Activity 2: Leaf Disk Assay Overview - 120 minutes

pageData.subTitle: Overview Video: Exploring Photosynthesis and Plant Pigments

text: Determine the number of pigments in a sample using paper chromatography.
Formulate hypotheses predicting the effect of varying light conditions and dissolved carbon dioxide concentration on the rate of oxygen production as a proxy for the rate of photosynthesis.
Collect and graph data. Use the data to explain the need for light and carbon dioxide on the light-dependent reaction of photosynthesis.

pageData.text: Life on Earth depends on plants. They perform many ecosystem functions and are the foundation of just about every food web. Plants provide us with food, materials to build structures and clothes, oxygen, fuel, and medicines. Plants not only take carbon out of the air, but they also detoxify it.

Air pollution is associated with many chronic diseases and cancer. According to NASA (1989), plants can remove many indoor air pollutants, including cigarette smoke, paints, and contaminants from plastics, such as formaldehyde and benzene. When indoor and outdoor plants absorb toxic gases through their leaves, they move into their roots. Microorganisms that live in the soil then break down and neutralize the toxins. Indoor house plants are not only attractive but also create a healthier living space.
ReferenceNASA. (1989). Interior landscape plants for indoor air pollution abatement - NASA technical reports server (NTRS). NASA. https://ntrs.nasa.gov/citations/19930073077

pageData.desc: A potted plant on a computer desk.
pageData.altText: A potted plant on a computer desk.

pageData.text: All living things need a source of outside energy. Animals get their energy from the food they eat. Plants obtain this energy from sunlight and convert the energy into a usable form by a process called photosynthesis.

pageData.subTitle: Chloroplasts and Photosynthesis
pageData.text: Plants, along with algae, cyanobacteria, and a few other organisms, perform photosynthesis using light energy to power a chemical reaction that yields energy, which can be stored as food. In plants, most photosynthesis occurs in the leaves, although some other parts of plants are also able to perform photosynthesis. Within the leaves, the mesophyll cells contain large numbers of chloroplasts. A cross section of a typical plant leaf (Figure 1.) reveals top, tight layers of palisade mesophyll cells. Below this is a lot of loosely arranged spongy mesophyll cells that allow for intercellular spaces. These spaces are continuous, with small openings in the lower leaf surface called (plural for “stoma”). The stomata allow gases such as carbon dioxide and oxygen to enter and exit the leaf. They also regulate the water content of the plant by evaporation by opening and closing.

pageData.desc: Figure 1: Cross section of a leaf showing the position of mesophyll cells and stoma. Chloroplsts are shown in the cells, and the intercellular space is labeled.
pageData.altText: Figure 1: Cross section of a leaf showing the position of mesophyll cells and stoma. Chloroplsts are shown in the cells, and the intercellular space is labeled.

pageData.text: Carbon dioxide, which is needed for the second part of the photosynthesis cycle, is found in the atmosphere and enters the leaf through the stomata, then diffuses into the mesophyll.

pageData.subTitle: Light-Dependent Reactions of Photosynthesis
pageData.text: In order to convert sunlight to chemical energy, plants contain a series of pigments to absorb sunlight. The most common of these are and and a group of pigments called . These pigments are located clustered together and anchored by proteins in the . In plants, this complex is located in the inside the plant’s chloroplasts. Each pigment has a distinct color dictated by the wavelengths of energy that it reflects. By contrast, the wavelengths that it absorbs are used to boost electrons to a higher energy state. As you can see in the picture, light that is not absorbed is reflected back. Thus a plant which looks green to us does not absorb the green light but reflects it back. In Figure 2 you can see that blue light is absorbed by the leaf. The energy absorbed is transferred to other pigment molecules via resonance energy transfer.

pageData.desc: Figure 2: Diagram showing how leaves reflect almost all green and yellow light, some orange and purple light, and absorb almost all blue, yellow and red light.
pageData.altText: Figure 2: Diagram showing how leaves reflect almost all green and yellow light, some orange and purple light, and absorb almost all blue, yellow and red light.

pageData.question: Why do most plants look green?

options.text: Green plants do not absorb green light.
Green plants do not absorb blue light.
Green plants do not absorb red light.
Green plants do not absorb white light.
Green plants do not absorb yellow light.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: A plant that looks green to us does not absorb green light but reflects it.

pageData.question: What are the most common plant pigments?

options.text: carotenoids, chlorophyll a, and chlorophyll b
chlorophyll a and chlorophyll b only

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The most common photosynthetic plant pigments are chlorophyll a and b, and a group of pigments called carotenoids.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: In order to convert sunlight to chemical energy, plants contain a series of pigments to absorb sunlight. The most common of these are chlorophyll a and b, and a group of pigments called carotenoids. These pigments are clustered together and anchored by proteins in the antenna complex. In plants, this complex is in the thylakoid membrane inside the chloroplasts. Each pigment has a distinct color dictated by the wavelengths of energy that it reflects. By contrast, the wavelengths that it absorbs are used to boost electrons to a higher energy state. The light that is not absorbed is reflected.

img.alt: Figure 2: Diagram showing how leaves reflect almost all green and yellow light, some orange and purple light, and absorb almost all blue, yellow and red light.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: In order to convert sunlight to chemical energy, plants contain a series of pigments to absorb sunlight. The most common of these are chlorophyll a and b, and a group of pigments called carotenoids. These pigments are clustered together and anchored by proteins in the antenna complex. In plants, this complex is in the thylakoid membrane inside the chloroplasts. Each pigment has a distinct color dictated by the wavelengths of energy that it reflects. By contrast, the wavelengths that it absorbs are used to boost electrons to a higher energy state. The light that is not absorbed is reflected.

img.alt: Figure 2: Diagram showing how leaves reflect almost all green and yellow light, some orange and purple light, and absorb almost all blue, yellow and red light.

pageData.text: In Figure 3 you can see the complex pathway the energy, in the form of an electron, will travel.

pageData.desc: Figure 3: Diagram showing the movement of electrons through the proteins in photsystem II and photosystem I.
pageData.altText: Figure 3: Diagram showing the movement of electrons through the proteins in photsystem II and photosystem I.

pageData.text: After the electron enters the photosystem it will first enter photosystem II. This system has its own pigment, P680. The number indicates the wavelength the pigment absorbs, in this case 680 nm. P680 transfers its high-energy electron to the primary electron acceptor, pheophytin. The electron lost by P680 is replaced by the oxidation of water. The oxidation of water produces oxygen gas O2 and hydrogen ions, which will be used later in the photosynthesis process, to help drive the proton pump that produces ATP. 2 H2O → O2 + 4H++ 4e-

The high-energy electron lost by P680 to pheophytin is subsequently transferred to a molecule called Q<sub>B</sub>, along with another electron and two hydrogen ions. Q<sub>B</sub> is part of the electron transport chain. By moving through the electron transport chain, excited electrons and the cytochrome complex facilitate the movement of hydrogen ions from the stroma to the thylakoid lumen, further increasing the electrochemical gradient across the membrane.

From the cytochrome complex, the high-energy electrons are passed to plastocyanin and then to another pigment molecule in photosystem I. The pigment associated with photosystem I (P700) reacts to a slightly different wavelength of light from the pigments in photosystem II (700 nm for photosystem I vs 680 nm for photosystem II). Each photosystem can work independently from the other, but receiving a high-energy electron from photosystem II, photosystem I can achieve an even higher energy level. It then passes two electrons to ferredoxin, which transfer a pair of electrons to NADP+ reductase. The role of NADP<sup>+</sup> reductase is to convert NADP<sup>+</sup> and hydrogen ions in the stroma to NADPH, the final electron acceptor, further reducing the concentration of hydrogen ions in the stroma.
The proton gradient is utilized by the enzyme ATP synthase to create ATP from ADP and phosphate. Both ATP and NADPH will be utilized in the Calvin Cycle.

pageData.subTitle: The Calvin Cycle
pageData.text: The Calvin Cycle is the process by which energy is transferred from short-term energy storage, ATP and NADPH, is used to fix carbon dioxide (CO2) into long-term energy storage molecules like glucose, sucrose, and starch. The process starts with the enzyme rubisco, catalyzing the fixation of three CO2 molecules and incorporating each into the sugar ribulose bisphosphate (RuBP). The product of this reaction splits into two molecules of 3-phosphoglycerate (3-PGA), yielding a total of six 3-PGA molecules. Energy from six ATP and six NADPH are used in subsequent reactions to produce six glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate (G3P) molecules. One of these is used as a building block for glucose or other carbohydrates, and the other five are recycled, with the addition of three more ATP into three RuBP molecules, which can cycle through again. The ADP and NADP+ produced in the cycle are reused in the light reactions.

pageData.desc: Figure 4: Diagram showing the Calvin Cycle with  carbon dioxide as an input and sugar as an output.
pageData.altText: Figure 4: Diagram showing the Calvin Cycle with  carbon dioxide as an input and sugar as an output.

pageData.subTitle: Pigments and Chromatography
pageData.text: Chromatography is a preferred analytical method for separating and identifying very small samples of a mixture. This analysis takes advantage of differences in the solubility and adsorption of substances by partitioning them between a mobile and a stationary phase. The mobile phase in this investigation is a liquid solvent, while the stationary phase is a solid (paper or silica gel). The chromatography activity will separate the pigments found in chloroplasts. Each pigment consists of a unique molecule whose properties give it a characteristic color. The paper chromatography has been designed to separate out different pigments if the sample contains more than one pigment. The pigments will dissolve in the solvent, isopropyl alcohol, and travel up the paper at different rates. Some will tend to bond more or less strongly to the cellulose in the paper and some are physically larger than others. These differences lead to the formation of different colored bands on the paper, one band for each pigment in the mixture. If the leaf contains only one pigment, expect to obtain only one color band.

In the second activity, an investigation will be conducted that examines the rate of photosynthesis in various light conditions and CO2 concentrations. Fresh leaf disks will be prepared and then the oxygen and carbon dioxide will be removed from the leaves. The leaf disks will then be placed in light or dark environments with various amounts of CO2 in solution. The number of floating disks will be used to indicate photosynthetic activity.

pageData.question: If the leaf contains only one pigment, what do expect to see on the chromatography paper?

options.text: two bands of the same color

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: If the leaf contains only one pigment, expect to obtain only a one-color band.

pageData.question: Which of the following substances carries pigment molecules along a paper chromatography strip?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: A liquid solvent, such as isopropyl alcohol, will dissolve the pigments and carry them up the chromatography paper at different rates.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Each pigment consists of a unique molecule whose properties give it a characteristic color. Paper chromatography has been designed to separate out different pigments if the sample contains more than one pigment. The pigments will dissolve in the solvent, isopropyl alcohol, and travel up the paper at different rates. Some will bond with varying strengths to the cellulose in the paper and some are physically larger than others. These differences lead to the formation of different colored bands on the paper, one band for each pigment in the mixture.

These differences lead to the formation of different colored bands on the paper, one band for each pigment in the mixture.

pageData.desc: A procedural workflow map of Activity 1. To start the activity, obtain plant leaves and cut the chromatography paper. Then, transfer the leaf pigment to the paper. Next, add alcohol solvent to a test tube and place the paper in the solvent. Allow the solvent to travel through paper until the solvent front is 1 centimeter from the top of the paper. Then, mark the solvent front and color bands. Finally, calculate the Rf value of each band. Continue to Activity 2.
pageData.altText: A procedural workflow map of Activity 1. To start the activity, obtain plant leaves and cut the chromatography paper. Then, transfer the leaf pigment to the paper. Next, add alcohol solvent to a test tube and place the paper in the solvent. Allow the solvent to travel through paper until the solvent front is 1 centimeter from the top of the paper. Then, mark the solvent front and color bands. Finally, calculate the Rf value of each band. Continue to Activity 2.

pageData.desc: Begin Activity 2 by setting up light and dark storage areas, preparing the soapy water and the baking soda solutions, and labelling the syringes. Then, cut out the leaf disks and extract the gas from the disks. Next, fill the syringes with baking soda solutions. To complete the light experiment, place the syringes in the light storage area and record the floating disks in 5-minute intervals. The experiment is complete when all the disks are floating or when 60 minutes have elapsed. Once the light experiment is complete, place the syringes in the dark storage area and record the floating disks in 5-minute intervals. Once all the disks are floating, or 60 minutes have elapsed, the activity is complete.
pageData.altText: Begin Activity 2 by setting up light and dark storage areas, preparing the soapy water and the baking soda solutions, and labelling the syringes. To complete the light experiment, place the syringes in the light storage area and record the floating disks in 5-minute intervals. The experiment is complete when all the disks are floating or when 60 minutes have elapsed. Once the light experiment is complete, place the syringes in the dark storage area and record the floating disks in 5-minute intervals. Once all the disks are floating, or 60 minutes have elapsed, the activity is complete.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes what a plant needs to complete photosynthesis?

options.text: carbon dioxide, water, and light energy

In which plant cells are chloroplasts primarily found?

options.text: Photosynthesis is initiated when chlorophyll molecules absorb light energy.
Photosynthesis is much more efficient during the daytime.
Photosynthesis fixes carbon dioxide into carbohydrate molecules.
Photosynthesis produces light energy as well as oxygen and ATP.
Photosynthesis does not require light to take place.

assestmentData.question: Why do plants have more than one type of photosynthetic pigment?

options.text: to capture a wider range of light wavelengths
to reflect the genetic diversity of their species
to cover the thylakoid membrane in more pigment molecules

its location in the leaf, size, and solubility

In Activity 1, you will use green leaves to isolate the pigments of photosynthesis using paper chromatography.
Spinach leaves are recommended, but any kind of tender, dark green leaf will work. Refrigerate cut leaves until ready for use.

typeBefore.title:
A
 Plant Pigments Overview
typeBefore.text: In this activity, paper chromatography will be used to determine if a green leaf contains only one pigment or a mixture of pigments.

pageData.text: Clean and sanitize work area.
Gather needed materials.
Hold the chromatography paper on the edges to avoid getting oils on the wicking surface.

Cut the piece of chromatography paper lengthwise into two, equal long strips. The extra strip is included should the experiment need to be repeated or the investigation is repeated with a second type of leaf.

At 1.5 cm from the bottom of the chromatography paper strip, draw a faint pencil line across the strip. This line will be the origin line. Click here to view a video demonstrating how to transfer pigment to your chromatography strip:

pageData.desc: Paper Chromatography: Transferring Pigment to paper

pageData.text: Lay a fresh spinach leaf on top of the origin line on the chromatography paper strip.
Roll the ribbed edge of the coin firmly on top of the leaf to press the pigments into the origin line.

If the line is not present or is faint, repeat the previous step but make sure the green pigments are on the origin line.
Reposition the leaf to ensure that the coin is rolling over fresh leaf tissue.
A vivid green stripe should be observed on the paper.
Place the plastic test tube in the test tube rack.

Add about 1 cm of isopropyl alcohol (approximately 20–25 drops) to the plastic test tube. The isopropyl alcohol will serve as the solvent that wicks and separates the plant pigments from the leaf up the paper.
Insert a straight pin into the center of each chromatography strip around 2 cm from the top. This will serve as a hanger for the strip when it is placed into the test tube.
Carefully lower the chromatography paper strip with the line oriented to the bottom, down the center of the test tube and into the solvent.

The strip should be in the center of the tube, not touching the walls. Adjust the strip’s position by moving the pin side to side. The origin line with the pigments from the spinach must be above the liquid level yet the bottom of the paper must be in the liquid.
Allow the solvent front to wick up the chromatography paper and through the vivid green line until the solvent front reaches within a centimeter of the top. This should take around 10–15 minutes.
Remove the chromatography paper strip from the tube.
Remove the pin from the strip.
Place the strip on a paper towel, and mark the solvent front with a pencil before the solvent evaporates. Now is also a good time to take a photo of the results.
Outline each of the colored spots that contain the plant pigments using the pencil and number of them from bottom to top.
Measure the distance in millimeters that the solvent front traveled from the origin line to the solvent front. Record this value in Data Table 1.
Measure the distance in millimeters that each colored spot moved, from the origin to the middle of the spot. Record these values in Data Table 1.

Many factors can affect the rate at which solvents and pigments move through the chromatography paper. In order to compare results across different runs, scientists use a ratio, called a Retention Factor (R<sub>f</sub>). The R<sub>f</sub> is the ratio of the distance traveled by the center of a pigment spot to the distance traveled by the solvent front.
In Activity 2, you will measure the rates of photosynthesis in leaf disks under various light conditions and carbon dioxide levels.
Spinach leaves are recommended, but any kind of tender, dark green leaf will work. Refrigerate cut leaves until ready for use.

typeBefore.title:
A
 Leaf Disk Assay Overview
typeBefore.text: In this activity, an investigation will be conducted that examines the rate of photosynthesis in various light conditions and CO<sub>2</sub> concentrations. Fresh leaf disks will be prepared and then the oxygen and carbon dioxide will be removed from the leaves. The leaf disks will then be placed in light or dark environments with various amounts of CO<sub>2</sub> in solution. The number of floating disks will be used to indicate photosynthetic activity.

pageData.text: Clean and sanitize work area and gather all necessary materials.
Set up a light storage area. Create a storage place under bright light. Use a grow light or desk lamp, positioned over desk or table surface. At least a 60-watt equivalent bulb is recommended.
Set up a dark storage area. Create a dark storage space in a cleared cupboard, a dark room, or under a box.
Prepare soapy water by adding a drop of dish soap to about 20mL of water in the medicine cup and swirl to mix.
Add the contents of the baking soda bottle/packet to a 250-mL beaker.
Carefully fill the beaker to 250 mL with tap water.
Stir with a dropper pipet until the mixture is suspended. Not all of the powder will go into solution.
Quickly, before the suspended mixture has a chance to settle out, measure out 5 mL of the solution into a 25 mL graduated cylinder.
Put the 5 mL in the second beaker. Label the second beaker 0.24%.
Fill the beaker to the 250-mL line. This is a 0.24% sodium bicarbonate solution.
Dispose of the contents of the first beaker. Be sure to rinse away all the residual bicarbonate.
Label the cleaned beaker 0.12%.
Place half of the 0.24% solution into the newly labeled beaker. Fill the 0.12% beaker with water to the 250-mL line. This is now a 0.12% solution.
Use the dropper pipet to transfer six drops of soapy water into the 0.24% beaker and 12 drops into the 0.12% beaker.
Label the 4 syringes “A”, “B”, “C”, and “D”.

Cut out 40–50 leaf disks from the healthiest-looking leaves:
  • Fill a small container with water.
  • Lay the leaf on a hard surface, protected by a paper towel.
  • Press the end of a plastic drinking straw into the leaf to cut a disk.
  • Gently squeeze and twist on the end of the straw to remove the disks. Try not to damage the interior of the leaf disks.
  • Keep the cut-out disks in the water container until you are ready to begin the experiment.
It is important that the sizes of the disks are almost identical to ensure the surface area in each experimental group is the same.
Click here to view a video demonstrating how to evacuate gas from the leaf disks:
Gently place 10 leaf disks into each of the four syringes. Use the straw to gently position the disks close to the syringe tip.
Replace the plunger and push towards the tip without smashing the disks.

Fill syringes “A” and “B” with solution from the “0.24%” beaker.
  • Place the syringe tip into the liquid.
  • Pull the plunger back to overfill the syringe to the 6-mL mark.
  • Tap any bubbles out.
  • Push the syringe tip firmly onto a syringe stand.

Remove as many of the bubbles as possible from the solution in the syringe. Do this by tapping the sides of the syringe and expelling the solution and bubbles. Refill the syringe if necessary to get 6 mL of bubble-free solution.

Fill syringes “C” and “D” with solution from the “0.12%” beaker.
  • Place the syringe tip into the liquid.
  • Pull the plunger back to overfill the syringe to the 6-mL mark.
  • Tap any bubbles out.
  • Push the syringe tip firmly onto a syringe stand.
For each syringe, pull the plunger back gently until a slight vacuum pressure is felt. Do not pull the plunger past the 9 mL mark on the syringe. If the plunger comes.
This vacuum will pull any air from the spaces within the tissue of the leaf disks. Small air bubbles will form on the disks as a more negative pressure is created.
out of the syringe, replace the leaves, refill the syringe with the appropriate solution, and begin again.
Gently shake the syringe or tap it on the side of the work surface while maintaining the vacuum. This should dislodge the air bubbles from the leaf disks.
Slowly release the plunger and allow the syringe to return to atmospheric pressure. Releasing the pressure suddenly may cause the cap to pop off.
Remove the cap and push out any gas that may have accumulated in the tip.
Continue the cycle of applying pressure and removing the cap until the leaf disks begin to sink, usually 2–5 cycles.
After the disks have sunk, turn the syringe tip and syringe stand up, then remove the syringe stand.
Remove any air bubbles and then fill the syringe to the 5-mL mark with the designated solution, and replace the syringe stand. Save the 0.12% and 0.24% solutions for the Dark Experiment.
Repeat steps 7–13 for each syringe.
At this time, each syringe should contain 5 mL of solution, no air bubbles, and all the leaf disks should be at the bottom of the syringe tube.
Place the syringes at the same time, with the syringe stand down, about 10 cm from the light source.
At 5-minute intervals, tap the sides of the syringe and then count the number of leaf disks that are floating. Collect data every 5 minutes for 60 minutes or until all disks are floating.
Record the data in Table 2.
Repeat the experiment above, except that instead of placing the syringes 10 cm from a light source, place them in a dark location as described in the preparation section.

Every 5 minutes, remove the syringes from the dark location, tap the sides of the syringe and then count the number of leaf disks that are floating. Collect data every 5 minutes for 60 minutes or until all disks are floating.
Record the data in Table 3.
Calculate the average number of disks floating per tube and graph the results to depict the number of floating leaf disks for each treatment over time.

text: Try substituting other green leaves, pigmented autumn leaves, flower petals, red cabbage, and skins of fruits and vegetables for the spinach leaf in the in the pigment chromatography activity.
Consider other factors that might affect the rate of photosynthesis. Design an experiment to test the effect of another factor on the rate of photosynthesis.
Dispose of the buffer, baking soda solution, and leftover isopropyl alcohol down the sink with excess water. Dispose of the chromatography paper strips in the household trash.
Wash and dry the syringe, medicine cup, and test tube and place them back into your kit.
Clean and sanitize your workspace.

pageData.title: Data Table 1. Chromatography of Plant Pigments

text: Many things can affect the evaporation of solvents during a chromatography experiment.  To allow researchers to compare results across experiments under different conditions, scientists use an Rf value, that is the ratio of the distance the pigment travelled to the distance the solvent travelled.  This number remains constant across trials.  Calculate the Rf value for each pigment.
Write a hypothesis for the leaf disk assay described in this activity.

According to your data, does light intensity affect the rate of photosynthesis? Explain.
How did the baking soda solution affect photosynthetic rates?

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Cross section of a leaf showing the position of mesophyll cells and stoma. Chloroplsts are shown in the cells, and the intercellular space is labeled.

pageData.content: Figure 2. Absorbed and reflected light of a green leaf
pageData.altText: Figure 2: Diagram showing how leaves reflect almost all green and yellow light, some orange and purple light, and absorb almost all blue, yellow and red light.
Figure 3: Diagram showing the movement of electrons through the proteins in photsystem II and photosystem I.
Figure 4: Diagram showing the Calvin Cycle with  carbon dioxide as an input and sugar as an output.

A procedural workflow map of Activity 1. To start the activity, obtain plant leaves and cut the chromatography paper. Then, transfer the leaf pigment to the paper. Next, add alcohol solvent to a test tube and place the paper in the solvent. Allow the solvent to travel through paper until the solvent front is 1 centimeter from the top of the paper. Then, mark the solvent front and color bands. Finally, calculate the R<sub>f</sub> value of each band. Continue to Activity 2.

Begin Activity 2 by setting up light and dark storage areas, preparing the soapy water and the baking soda solutions, and labelling the syringes. Then, cut out the leaf disks and extract the gas from the disks. Next, fill the syringes with baking soda solutions. To complete the light experiment, place the syringes in the light storage area and record the floating disks in 5-minute intervals. The experiment is complete when all the disks are floating or when 60 minutes have elapsed. Once the light experiment is complete, place the syringes in the dark storage area and record the floating disks in 5-minute intervals. Once all the disks are floating, or 60 minutes have elapsed, the activity is complete.

pageData.content: Paper Chromatography: Transferring Pigment to paper

data.title: Antenna complex
data.content: a light-harvesting membrane-associated group of proteins and photosensitive pigments in the thylakoid membrane of plant chloroplasts

data.title: Carotenoids
data.content: a group of pigments that includes yellow, orange, and red organic pigments

data.title: Chlorophyll a
data.content: a green pigment present in all green plants and in cyanobacteria

data.title: Chlorophyll b
data.content: a green pigment that primarily absorbs blue light

data.title: Stomata
data.content: small openings in the lower leaf surface that allow gases, such as carbon dioxide and oxygen, to enter and exit the leaf; they also regulate the evaporation of water by opening and closing; singular, stoma

data.title: Thylakoid membrane
data.content: membrane-bound compartments inside chloroplasts and cyanobacteria; it is the site of the light-dependent reactions of photosynthesis
